ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Sensorineural Hearing Loss (Presbycusis)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Bilateral, slightly asymmetric high-frequency SNHL consistent with age-related hearing loss.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Diagnosed by geriatrician and neuropsychologist (amnestic MCI); impacts auditory processing and rehabilitation strategy.

ordered_list.rationale_short: Assess hearing thresholds given patient age and reported communication difficulties.
Evaluate speech reception thresholds and word recognition abilities.
Assess signal-to-noise ratio loss using BKB-SIN, which is less taxing on memory for patients with cognitive impairment.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Testing revealed bilateral, slightly asymmetric high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss, sloping to moderate/moderately-severe levels. Speech recognition in quiet was excellent, and speech-in-noise performance (BKB-SIN) was within normal limits. Middle ear function was normal. Acoustic reflexes were largely present, though contralateral right stimulation was absent; however, retrocochlear pathology was not suspected due to a recent negative neurology workup.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Normal thresholds through 1000 Hz, sloping to moderate (Right) and moderately-severe (Left) high-frequency SNHL.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRT 25 dB HL bilaterally; WRS 100% at 60 dB HL bilaterally; LDLs > 110 dB HL.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Ipsilateral present bilaterally; Contralateral present left stim, absent right stim.

tests.name: Speech-in-noise
tests.result_summary: BKB-SIN score 2.5 dB SNR loss (within normal limits).

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Hearing Aid Evaluation: Discussed lifestyle needs, cosmetic concerns, and cognitive status. Administered COSI to identify communication goals. Selected bilateral premium rechargeable RIC hearing aids.
Hearing Aid Fitting: Fitted with bilateral RIC hearing aids using open domes. Counseled on use and care.
Follow-up (2 weeks post-fitting): Patient reported hearing aids were very helpful. COSI indicated 'better' or 'much better' hearing in 3/4 situations. Rated ability to hear as 'almost always'.
Unscheduled Visit (same week as V4): Reported hearing aids falling out despite correct insertion. Impressions taken for custom earmolds to improve retention.

Custom Earmold Fitting (2 weeks after V5): Patient had great difficulty inserting custom molds and handling charger (dead batteries). Wife distressed about his cognitive decline. Psychologist consulted during session. Red dot placed on charger to assist.
Follow-up (3 weeks after V6): Patient returned hearing aids due to management difficulties and frustration. Couple decided to 'take a break'.
Re-fitting (1 month after V7): Patient requested new prescription. Agreed to proceed with RICs but with a different style of custom earmolds for better retention.
Final Follow-up (3 months after V8): Patient reported significant benefit and successful use with wife's assistance.

proposed_items: Trial period with bilateral premium rechargeable Receiver-In-The-Canal (RIC) hearing aids
Initial fitting with open domes, later switched to custom earmolds due to retention issues
Group rehabilitation classes (AR classes) for new hearing aid users
Use of visual cues (red dot on charger) to assist with device management
Referral to specialized social worker program for caregiver support
Referral to 'Learning the Ropes for Living with MCI' cognitive intervention program
counseling_actions: Educate on the link between hearing loss, cognitive decline, and listening effort
Involve wife in all appointments to reduce caregiver burden and assist with device management
Discuss realistic expectations regarding progressive cognitive decline
Counsel on behavioral communication strategies and environmental modifications
Keep technology simple to minimize cognitive demand

escalation.rationale_short: Red flag findings (asymmetry, absent reflex) were noted but referral to ENT was not made as the patient had recently undergone a full neurology workup which ruled out retrocochlear pathology.

follow_up_plan.timeline: Hearing aid check at 2 weeks, with subsequent visits at 3 weeks, 1 month, and 3 months.
follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor device use, address retention/handling difficulties, and support the patient and wife in adaptation.

expected_outcome: COSI: Patient reported hearing 'better' or 'much better' in 3 out of 4 target situations and rated ability to hear as 'almost always'.
Device Management: Initial difficulties with retention (domes) and insertion/charging (first custom molds) required multiple modifications and retraining.
Final Status: After 3 months and a switch to a different style of custom earmolds, patient reported significant benefit and successful use with wife's assistance.
